Stenographers create and file written records of legal events, such as trials, depositions, meetings, or other judicial proceedings. Because of the importance placed on accuracy in legal documentation, these records are transcribed verbatim. Legal stenographers will require at least an associates degree,             What Are the Job Duties    In addition to creating the written records, stenographers may also be responsible for researching and organizing information to be put in the official record. In some cases, stenographers assist with courtroom administrative procedures. Some stenographers use their skills outside the courtroom to work in closed captioning for television and films. Some specific duties of a Legal stenographer include:       Attending hearings, proceedings and depositions     Capturing all spoken words, gestures and audible sounds verbatim     Reviewing notes and researching technical terminology     Reading and editing transcripts for accuracy     Providing transcripts and recordings to all parties involved in a proceeding
